title: Kolkata
summary: Kolkata is the capital of the Indian state of West Bengal. The city is widely regarded as the "cultural capital" of India, and is also nicknamed the "City of Joy".

value.label: Kolkata's recorded history began in 1690 with the arrival of the English East India Company, which was consolidating its trade business in Bengal. The area occupied by the present-day city encompassed three villages: Kalikata, Gobindapur, and Sutanuti.

Spread roughly north–south along the east bank of the Hooghly River, Kolkata sits within the lower Ganges Delta of eastern India approximately 75 km (47 mi) west of the international border with Bangladesh.

value.label: Kolkata has been called the "City of Furious, Creative Energy" as well as the "cultural [or literary] capital of India".

image.altText: Kolkata has been called the "City of Furious, Creative Energy" as well as the "cultural [or literary] capital of India".
image.license: This file is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 4.0 International license.

value.label: Kolkata has many buildings adorned with Indo-Islamic and Indo-Saracenic architectural motifs. Several well-maintained major buildings from the colonial period have been declared "heritage structures".

image.altText: Kolkata has many buildings adorned with Indo-Islamic and Indo-Saracenic architectural motifs. Several well-maintained major buildings from the colonial period have been declared "heritage structures".
image.license: This file is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 3.0 Unported license.

value.label: Kolkata is the home of the Bengali cinema industry, dubbed "Tollywood" for Tollygunj, where most of the state's film studios are located.

image.altText: Kolkata is the home of the Bengali cinema industry, dubbed "Tollywood" for Tollygunj, where most of the state's film studios are located.
image.license: This file is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 4.0 International license.

value.label: Though Bengali women traditionally wear the sari, the shalwar kameez and Western attire is gaining acceptance among younger women. Western-style dress has greater acceptance among men, although the traditional dhoti and kurta are seen during festivals.

image.altText: Though Bengali women traditionally wear the sari, the shalwar kameez and Western attire is gaining acceptance among younger women. Western-style dress has greater acceptance among men, although the traditional dhoti and kurta are seen during festivals.
